I'm going to take a wild guess here that your son asked for a Cuban cigar. If that's the case, forget it. Educate your son instead. Duties and taxes here force authentic Cuban cigars to be nearly prohibitively expensive. At minimum, a very poor value as compared to a fine Dominican or Nicaraguan cigar. Further, Cubans today aren't what they were 10 years ago. Have your son check any Cigar Aficionado magazine for their ratings.But that's the simple part. The more important point is that this region is saturated by fake Cubans. Unless you're an expert, you'll never be able to distinguish the 1% of authentic Cubans here. That's right -I'd guess that 99% are fakes. Now, if the word "Cuban" was never referenced, I'd still refrain from buying a cigar here. My local tobacconist stores, sells and provides much better value, and I'm going to guess that yours does too. Buy a different souvenir, like some fine tequila, non-export of course.

By the way, I am a cigar smoker, and the absolute *worst* cigar I've ever had the misfortune of paying for and tasting was one of those being hand rolled on 5th Ave in Playa. In a word -Nasty. 2pulls and that thing went from mouth to curb.Learned my lesson that year, and have been bringing my own from home ever since.Edited: 6 years ago
